conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a dark area on a surface. The position and size of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
In the image, there are four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D. The light source is currently positioned such that it casts these shadows on the ground.

premise: When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), the angle at which light hits the objects changes.
conclusion: As the light source moves further away, the shadows will generally become longer because the light rays are more parallel to the surface.

premise: When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), the angle at which light hits the objects changes.
conclusion: The position of the shadows will shift in the direction opposite to the movement of the light source. If the light source moves backward, the shadows will move forward (away from the light source).

premise: Shadow A is cast by the object closest to the light source.
conclusion: As the light source moves backward, shadow A will elongate and move forward on the ground.

premise: Shadow B is cast by an object.
conclusion: Shadow B will elongate and move forward, similar to shadow A. The extent of elongation depends on the height and shape of the object casting shadow B.

premise: Shadow C is further from the light source initially.
conclusion: Shadow C will experience a significant elongation and forward movement. The shadow may become more diffuse if the light source moves far enough away.

premise: Shadow D is cast by an object.
conclusion: Shadow D will elongate and move forward as well. The size increase will be noticeable, especially if the object casting shadow D is tall.

premise: As the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all elongate and move forward on the ground.
conclusion: The shadows will become longer due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects, and their positions will shift forward, away from the light source.
